member.name: T:Syncfusion.Windows.Chart.ChartTypes
member.summary: Enumeration represents all built-in chart types. Different sets of data are particularly suited to a certain chart type.

member.name: F:Syncfusion.Windows.Chart.ChartTypes.Area
member.summary: A type of presentation graphic that emphasizes a change in values by filling in the portion of the graph beneath the line connecting various data points.

member.name: F:Syncfusion.Windows.Chart.ChartTypes.Bar
member.summary: A bar chart, also known as a bar graph, is a chart with rectangular bars of lengths proportional to that value that they represent. Bar charts are used for comparing two or more values.

member.name: F:Syncfusion.Windows.Chart.ChartTypes.BoxAndWhisker
member.summary: A box and whisker chart type is a convenient way of graphically depicting groups of numerical data through their five-number summaries (the smallest observation, lower quartile (Q1), median (Q2), upper quartile (Q3), and largest observation). A box and whisker chart may also indicate which observations, if any, might be considered outliers.
member.remarks: Box and whisker chart is helpful in Quality Analysis for interpreting the distribution of data since it can easily show whether the data is skewed and if there are unusual observations (outliers) in the dataset. Box and whisker chart is also very useful when large numbers of observations are involved and when two or more datasets are being compared.

member.name: F:Syncfusion.Windows.Chart.ChartTypes.Bubble
member.summary: A bubble chart draws bubbles for each point in a series. The chart expects three values per bubble: the domain (commonly the X-axis) value and, the range (commonly the y-axis) value.

member.name: F:Syncfusion.Windows.Chart.ChartTypes.Candle
member.summary: A candlestick chart is a style of bar-chart used primarily to describe price movements of an equity over time. It is a combination of a line-chart and a bar-chart, in that each bar represents the range of price movement over a given time interval. It is most often used in technical analysis of equity and currency price patterns. It appears superficially similar to error bars, but are unrelated.

member.name: F:Syncfusion.Windows.Chart.ChartTypes.Column
member.summary: Compares values across categories. The series values are displayed as individual columns, grouped by category. The height of each column is determined by the series value.
member.remarks: There are three types of column charts: column, , and .

member.name: F:Syncfusion.Windows.Chart.ChartTypes.Doughnut
member.summary: A doughnut chart displays value data as percentages of the whole. Categories are represented by individual slices. Doughnut charts are typically used to show percentages. Doughnut charts are functionally identical to pie charts.

member.name: F:Syncfusion.Windows.Chart.ChartTypes.FastLine
member.summary: When performance is critical, the FastLine chart type is a good alternative to the Line chart. FastLine chart significantly reduce the drawing time of a series that contains a very large number of data points.

member.name: F:Syncfusion.Windows.Chart.ChartTypes.FastBar
member.summary: When performance is critical, the FastBar chart type is a good alternative to the Bar chart. FastBar chart significantly reduce the drawing time of a series that contains a very large number of data points.

member.name: F:Syncfusion.Windows.Chart.ChartTypes.FastSpline
member.summary: When performance is critical, the FastSpline chart type is a good alternative to the Spline chart. FastSpline chart significantly reduce the drawing time of a series that contains a very large number of data points.

member.name: F:Syncfusion.Windows.Chart.ChartTypes.Funnel
member.summary: The Funnel Chart type displays data that equals 100% when totalled. This type of chart is a single series chart representing the data as portions of 100%, and this chart does not use any axes.

member.name: F:Syncfusion.Windows.Chart.ChartTypes.Gantt
member.summary: A Gantt chart is a type of bar chart that shows a project schedule. Gantt charts show the start and finish dates of the terminal elements and summary elements of a project. Terminal elements and summary elements comprise the work breakdown structure of the project. Gantt charts can be used to show current schedule status using percent-complete shadings and a vertical "TODAY" line (also called "TIME NOW" or "DATA DATE"). It is an instrument or tool of the Project management invented by the engineer Henry L. Gannt.

member.name: F:Syncfusion.Windows.Chart.ChartTypes.HiLo
member.summary: HiLo chart is a sophisticated chart type, that finds its place in stock analysis.
member.remarks:
Key Features:
* Display of Error Bars.
* Trading range of stock and its closing value, for each period.
* Displays Y - value for each X - value.
* In special cases, displays a range of Y - values for a given X value.

member.name: F:Syncfusion.Windows.Chart.ChartTypes.HiLoOpenClose
member.summary: HiLo OpenClose Chart is a HiLo chart with four Y values for each point.
member.remarks:
The functionality of each Y value is given below:
* One representing the high value of the plotted stock, for the time period for which the chart is being rendered.
* One representing the low values for the same period.
* One representing the opening value for that period.
* One representing the closing value for that period.

member.name: F:Syncfusion.Windows.Chart.ChartTypes.Histogram
member.summary: Represents a graphical display of tabulated frequencies. A histogram is the graphical version of a table that shows what proportion of cases fall into each of several or many specified categories. The histogram differs from a bar chart in that it is the area of the bar that denotes the value, not the height, a crucial distinction when the categories are not of uniform width. The categories are usually specified as non-overlapping intervals of some variable. The categories (bars) must be adjacent.

member.name: F:Syncfusion.Windows.Chart.ChartTypes.Kagi
member.summary: A Kagi chart is created with a series of vertical lines connected by short horizontal lines. The thickness and direction of the lines is based on the price of the underlying stock or asset

member.name: F:Syncfusion.Windows.Chart.ChartTypes.Line
member.summary: A style of chart that is created by connecting a series of data points together with a line. This is the most basic type of chart used in finance and it is generally created by connecting a series of past prices together with a line.

member.name: F:Syncfusion.Windows.Chart.ChartTypes.Pie
member.summary: A pie chart (or a circle graph) is a circular chart divided into sectors, illustrating relative magnitudes or frequencies or percents. In a pie chart, the arc length of each sector (and consequently its central angle and area), is proportional to the quantity it represents. Together, the sectors create a full disk. It is named for its resemblance to a pie which has been sliced.

member.name: F:Syncfusion.Windows.Chart.ChartTypes.PointAndFigure
member.summary:
A point and figure chart is used for technical analysis of securities. Unlike most other investment charts, point and figure charts do not present a linear representation of time. Instead, they show trends in price.
The aim of point and figure charting is to filter out the "noise" (unimportant price movement) and focus on the main direction of the price trend.
Point and figure charts are usually used for longer term price movements, but may be used to day trade by trying to identify the key points of "supply and demand." Point and figure charts are close relatives to , and charts which all do not have a fixed time frame.

member.name: F:Syncfusion.Windows.Chart.ChartTypes.Polar
member.summary: Polar chart is used to display chart data points, connected with a line, in a polar co-ordinate system.

member.name: F:Syncfusion.Windows.Chart.ChartTypes.Pyramid
member.summary: Pyramid charts are another type of accumulation chart which has a triangular upper surface that converge at one point. Similar to a chart, the height of a segment is proportional to the Y value of the corresponding point.

member.name: F:Syncfusion.Windows.Chart.ChartTypes.Radar
member.summary: A radar chart is two-dimensional chart of three or more quantitative variables represented on axes starting from the same point. The relative position and angle of the axes is uninformative. Radar charts are usually used to compare performance of different entities on a same set of axes.

member.name: F:Syncfusion.Windows.Chart.ChartTypes.RangeArea
member.summary: Range Area Chart is a variation of Area Chart type that lets you plot bands of data in a chart, like Bollinger bands, weather patterns, etc. Each point in the chart is specified by 2 Y values the lower and higher end of the band.

member.name: F:Syncfusion.Windows.Chart.ChartTypes.RangeColumn
member.summary: Columns connecting minimum and maximum series points with the same respective X.

member.name: F:Syncfusion.Windows.Chart.ChartTypes.Renko
member.summary: A renko chart is constructed by placing a brick in the next column once the price surpasses the top or bottom of the previous brick by a pre-defined amount. Lighter bricks are used when the direction of the trend is up, while darker bricks are used when the trend is down. This type of chart is very effective for traders to identify key support/resistance levels. Transaction signals are generated when the direction of the trend changes and the bricks alternate colors.

member.name: F:Syncfusion.Windows.Chart.ChartTypes.RotatedSpline
member.summary: Rotated Spline chart defines chart series points as interconnected rotated smooth curves.

member.name: F:Syncfusion.Windows.Chart.ChartTypes.Scatter
member.summary: A scatter type contains one or more scatter plots each of which use Cartesian coordinates to display values for two series values for a set of data. The data is displayed as a collection of points, each having the value of one variable determining the position on the horizontal axis and the value of the other variable determining the position on the vertical axis.

member.name: F:Syncfusion.Windows.Chart.ChartTypes.Spline
member.summary: A spline chart is simply a line chart that plots a fitted curve through each data point in a series.

member.name: F:Syncfusion.Windows.Chart.ChartTypes.SplineArea
member.summary: Spline Chart is an Area chart in which each area is given a color to emphasize the relationships between the pieces of charted information.

member.name: F:Syncfusion.Windows.Chart.ChartTypes.StackingArea
member.summary: StackingArea is an area chart with Y values stacked over one another, in series order.

member.name: F:Syncfusion.Windows.Chart.ChartTypes.StackingArea100
member.summary: StackingArea100 is an area chart with Y values stacked over one another for 100%, in series order.

member.name: F:Syncfusion.Windows.Chart.ChartTypes.StackingBar
member.summary: A stacked bar chart displays the relationship of individual items to the whole, comparing the contributions of each value to a total across categories. The series values are stacked in a single column for each category. The height of each column is determined by the total of all series values for the category.

member.name: F:Syncfusion.Windows.Chart.ChartTypes.StackingBar100
member.summary: A bar chart where multiple series are stacked horizontally to fit 100% of the chart area. If there is only one series in chart, all the bars will fit to 100% of area.

member.name: F:Syncfusion.Windows.Chart.ChartTypes.StackingColumn
member.summary: A stacked column chart displays the relationship of individual items to the whole, comparing the contributions of each value to a total across categories. The series values are stacked in a single column for each category. The height of each column is determined by the total of all series values for the category.

member.name: F:Syncfusion.Windows.Chart.ChartTypes.StackingColumn100
member.summary: A column chart where multiple series are stacked vertically to fit 100% of the chart area. If there is only one series in your chart, all the column bars will fit to 100% of the chart area.

member.name: F:Syncfusion.Windows.Chart.ChartTypes.StackingLine
member.summary: StackingLine is a line chart with Y values stacked over one another, in series order.

member.name: F:Syncfusion.Windows.Chart.ChartTypes.StackingLine100
member.summary: StackingLine100 is a line chart with Y values stacked over one another for 100%, in series order.

member.name: F:Syncfusion.Windows.Chart.ChartTypes.StackingSpline
member.summary: StackingSpline is a spline chart with Y values stacked over one another, in series order.

member.name: F:Syncfusion.Windows.Chart.ChartTypes.StackingSpline100
member.summary: StackingSpline100 is a spline chart with Y values stacked over one another for 100%, in series order.

member.name: F:Syncfusion.Windows.Chart.ChartTypes.StackingSplineArea
member.summary: StackingSplineArea is a splinearea chart with Y values stacked over one another, in series order.

member.name: F:Syncfusion.Windows.Chart.ChartTypes.StackingSplineArea100
member.summary: StackingSplineArea100 is a splinearea chart with Y values stacked over one another for 100%, in series order.

member.name: F:Syncfusion.Windows.Chart.ChartTypes.StepArea
member.summary: The StepArea chart consists of pairs of values (plotted as points) on a line for each series in the given dataset. Each pair of values consists of one date (value) and one numeric value. This chart will have one date\time (value) based axis (the domain axis) and one numeric axis (the range axis). Each line is drawn at a 90 degree angle from point to point. Each line will fill the from the line to the bottom of the plot with its series color.

member.name: F:Syncfusion.Windows.Chart.ChartTypes.StepLine
member.summary: Step Line charts are line charts, with values drawn continuously, step by step without any gaps between them.

member.name: F:Syncfusion.Windows.Chart.ChartTypes.ThreeLineBreak
member.summary: ThreeLineBreak displays a series of vertical boxes that are based on changes in prices. It depicts rising and falling lines of varying heights.

member.name: F:Syncfusion.Windows.Chart.ChartTypes.Tornado
member.summary: Tornado chart is a bar chart, which shows the variability of an outcome, as the result of several factors. This variability is displayed using relative lengths of bars across a range.

member.name: F:Syncfusion.Windows.Chart.ChartTypes.FastColumn
member.summary: FastColumn Chart is a Column Chart, Which Comes under FastChartType

member.name: F:Syncfusion.Windows.Chart.ChartTypes.FastStackingColumn
member.summary: FastStackingColumn Chart is a Column Chart, Which Comes under FastChartType

member.name: F:Syncfusion.Windows.Chart.ChartTypes.FastScatter
member.summary: FastScatter Chart is a Scatter Chart, Which Comes under FastChartType

member.name: F:Syncfusion.Windows.Chart.ChartTypes.FastHiLoOpenClose
member.summary: FastHiLoOpenClose Chart is a Fast Chart Type.

member.name: F:Syncfusion.Windows.Chart.HeatMapLayoutMode.SliceAndDiceVertical
member.summary: Items will be laid out vertically one after another. The type is used to host the items.

member.name: F:Syncfusion.Windows.Chart.HeatMapLayoutMode.Squarified
member.summary: Lays out child items within the available space in rectangles with aspect ratio that is closer to 1.
